results.title: Face of South Africa
results.creator_credit: Raymond Hancock, Errol Hinds, Malcolm Lomberg and South African Screen Productions
results.brief_description: By imaginative use of photographs, shows many facets of the peoples of South Africa. In youth, adolescence and age; at leisure and work; in joy, sorrow and excitement. Photography by Raymond Hancock with commentary and narration by Frank Secker.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Raymond Hancock, Errol Hinds, Malcolm Lomberg and South African Screen Productions

results.title: The Face of Red China
results.creator_credit: Av Westin, Leslie Midgley and CBS News
results.brief_description: Walter Cronkite interviews Gerald Clark, an experienced Canadian reporter, against a background of film photographed in China by Rolf Gilhausen in 1958. This film covers life on farms, in cities and factories in a country which was then rapidly becoming a real Marxist state, with communal life and communal ownership. Vast resources of human energy were used on the building of dams and bridges with very few machines. The fundamental changes in family life, the indoctrination program, the question of Soviet assistance and the growth of secondary industry.

results.title: Face of Malaya
results.brief_description: Malaya is populated by people of many races e.g. Chinese, Indians, Malays. This film shows the signing of the Federation of the Malay States - the first step towards their independence - and how this was celebrated throughout the land by young and old alike. Also points out importance of Malaya’s two greatest industries, tin and rubber.

results.title: Face
results.creator_credit: Robin Spry, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film is a visual experiment, an exploration into the past, present and projected life of a young woman as seen on her face. A broad range of emotions are held up to the camera, both rehearsed and unrehearsed by this professional actress Julie Wildman. (Award: Niagara-on-the-Lake). Photography by Robin Spry and Kjeld Nielsen, sound by John Knight.

results.title: A Fable for friendship
results.creator_credit: Jiri Trnka, Czechoslovak State Film and Unesco
results.brief_description: Animated fable to show what can be achieved by the exchange of ideas and skills between peoples. Explains that the Y shape of the new UNESCO headquarters building is a symbol of the meeting place where peoples of 100 nations come together to benefit from what each has learned in the field of education, science and culture.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jiri Trnka, Czechoslovak State Film and Unesco

results.title: A Fable by Aesop: The North wind and the sun
results.creator_credit: Les Drew, Rhoda Leyer, Robert Verrall and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An engaging illustration, by animation artist Rhoda Leyer, of the ancient Greek fable in which the warm sun proves to the cold wind that persuasion is better than force when it comes to making a man take off his overcoat. Music by Karl Duplessis.

results.title: A Fable
results.creator_credit: Rolf W. Brandis, Fred A Niles, William Clarkson and Xerox
results.brief_description: Like all fables, “A Fable” presents an idea in concrete form. In this case, the benefits of friendly co-operation that entails inevitable risks are contrasted with the miseries of self-imposed hostile isolation that avoids such risks. Shot on location near a 14th century village north of Rome, its cast includes the famous French pantomimist Marcel Marceau. It tells of a story of a man who, in order to protect his property, builds a wall to block out the world and consequently experiences loneliness and despair. The children eventually return and together with the man, pull down the wall and build a bridge across the stream which separates the man’s world and the children’s.

results.title: Fabienne
results.creator_credit: Jacques Godbout, Andre Belleau and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: She is a night club entertainer, in her way a highly successful exponent of her art, but there are moments when the admiration of her Montreal following is not enough. “Fabienne” is the portrait of a woman who has achieved enviable fame but is still far from content. (Award: Evian) Credits include: photographer by Guy Borremans; editing by Jacques Godbout, Gilles Groulx; music by Pierre Letourneau and sound by Joseph Champagne.

results.title: F.A. Cup Final 1967
results.brief_description: A brilliant finale to the 1967 British football season between the two London teams, Tottenham Hotspurs and Chelsea as they battle it out for the FA Cup at Wembley Stadium.

results.title: The Cup Final [1966]
results.brief_description: Opens with a dressing room scene before the commencement of play at Wembley of the 1966 FA Cup Final championship between two great English northern teams, Everton and Sheffield Wednesday.
